children.name: move
children.definition: /muːv/  to go to a different place or to change the position of your body:
examples: dịch chuyển, di chuyển
▪ Every time I move I get a pain in my left shoulder.
▪ Don’t move, there’s a spider on your back.
move away/forward/towards etc
đi khỏi / lên / về phía vv
▪ Sarah moved away from the window.
▪ My mother moved forward and grabbed my wrist.
move aroundto different parts of an area
đi lại
▪ I can hear someone moving around downstairs!

children.name: movement
children.definition: /ˈmuːvmənt/  when someone or something moves:chuyển động
examples: ▪ Any movement will set off the alarm.
▪ He watched her graceful movements as she came towards him.
▪ The doctor thinks she’ll recover quite a lot of movement, though maybe not all.
movement of
chuyển động của
▪ the movement of the human heart
movement towards/across/through etc
chuyển động về phía/ngang qua/qua...
▪ Make gentle sweeping movements across the hedge so that the blade can cut on both sides.
sudden movement
cử động đột ngột
▪ I crept to the door, and with a sudden movement, opened it wide.

children.name: stir
children.definition: /stɜːʳ/  especially written to make a slight movement, for example just before you wake up or start to speak:cựa quậy
examples: ▪ The sleeping child stirred and opened her eyes
▪ The crowd began to stir as the band walked on stage.

children.name: make a move
children.definition: /ˌmeɪk ə ˈmuːv/  to make a movement, especially as you start to do something or try to do something:di chuyển
examples: ▪ ‘The dog won’t touch you,’ she said , ‘unless you make a move towards me.’
▪ He made a move to kiss me, but I turned away.

children.name: move over
children.definition: B /ˌmuːv ˈəʊvəʳ/  to move to a different position in a bed, on a chair etc:xích qua, nhích qua
examples: ▪ Move over a bit, I’m falling out of bed.
▪ Penelope moved over and took the driver’s seat.

children.name: shift
children.definition: /ʃɪft/  British informal to move from one place or position to another, or to make something do this:di chuyển, đổi chỗ
examples: ▪ Jonas stood and listened, shifting uncomfortably from one foot to the other.
▪ The sun had shifted to the west.
▪ She shifted her gaze from me to Bobby with a look of suspicion.
▪ The building’s foundation has shifted, which is why there are cracks in the plaster.
shift your legs/arm/foot etc
di chuyển chân/tay/bàn chân... của bạn
▪ Tell Alan to shift his feet so Maggie can sit down.
▪ The leather armchair creaked as Roberts shifted his bulk.

children.name: to move st from one place or position to another
move
children.definition: /muːv/  to take something to a different place or change the position of something:
examples: di chuyển
▪ Will you move your car, please? It’s blocking the road.
▪ It took three men to move the piano.
move something to/into something
di chuyển cái gì đó tới/vào cái gì đó
▪ We’ll have to move the table into the hall.

children.name: transfer
children.definition: /trænsˈfɜːʳ/  to move something and put it in a different place or container:
examples: dời, chuyển, dọn, nhượng
▪ Transfer the mixture to a heavy cooking pan and add all remaining ingredients.
transfer something (from something) to something
dời, chuyển, dọn, nhượng cái gì đó (từ cái gì đó) tới cái gì đó
▪ Could I transfer $500 from my savings to my checking account?

children.name: shift
children.definition: /ʃɪft/  British informal to move something from where it is:đổi chỗ, dời chỗ
examples: ▪ When are you going to shift all this rubbish? It’s making the place look a real mess.
▪ Come on Des, give me a hand to shift these and then we can go home.

children.name: swing
children.definition: /swɪŋ/  to move something quickly through the air with a long circular movement:vung
examples: ▪ She swung the ax, hitting the log squarely in the middle.
swing something back/over/across etc
vung cái gì đó về/qua/ngang qua...
▪ As you swing the golf club back, try to keep your eye on the ball.
swing[countable noun]cú vung
▪ With a heavy swing of the mallet, he drove the post into the ground.

children.name: jerk
children.definition: /dʒɜːʳk/  to move something with a short, very sudden movement:giật
examples: jerk something away/towards/up etc
giật cái gì đó khỏi/về phía/ngược lên...
▪ Mark jerked the phone away from the girl.
▪ Graham had to jerk the steering wheel to the left to avoid a crash.
jerk[countable noun]cú giật
▪ The train moved off with a jerk.

children.name: to keep moving your body or part of your body
fidget
children.definition: /ˈfɪdʒɪt, ˈfɪdʒət/  to keep moving or playing with your fingers, hands, feet etc, because you areboredornervous:
examples: cựa quậy, nhúc nhích
▪ Stop fidgeting, Sally, and pay attention.
fidget in your seat/chair
cựa quậy, nhúc nhích trên ghế
▪ She glared at the little boy, who had started fidgeting in his chair.
fidget with
bồn chồn với
▪ Diana fidgeted nervously with her pencil.

children.name: can’t keep still
children.definition: /ˌkɑːnt kiːp ˈstɪlǁˌkænt-/ spokenif you can’t keep still, you keep moving your body because you areexcitedornervousand you cannot relax:
examples: không thể đứng yên
▪ I was so excited that I couldn’t keep still.
▪ Frankie has a lot of energy; he can hardly keep still for more than a few minutes.

children.name: twitch
children.definition: /twɪtʃ/  if part of your body twitches, it makes small movements that you cannot control:
examples: co rúm, giật giật
▪ A muscle on Yang’s face twitched.
▪ My right eyelid wouldn’t stop twitching.
twitch[countable noun]
sự co rúm, chứng co giật
▪ It’s just a nervous twitch.
▪ There was a twitch in my left cheek which I couldn’t control.

children.name: squirm
children.definition: /skwɜːʳm/  to make very small movements from side to side with your body, especially because you are in pain or uncomfortable:vặn vẹo, quằn quại
examples: ▪ The cat was squirming and he put it down.
▪ Diane squirmed wildly as Gavin tickled her.
squirm in your seat/chair
vặn vẹo, quằn quại trên ghế
▪ The little boy squirmed in his seat, anxious to get up and leave the table.
squirm with embarrassment/discomfort etc
cảm thấy lúng túng vì ngại/không thoải mái...
▪ Laura’s face reddened and she squirmed with embarrassment.

children.name: wriggle
children.definition: /ˈrɪgəl/  to make small movements from side to side, especially in order to get into a particular position or to get through an opening:len, luồn, lách
examples: wriggle into/out/through etc
lẻn vào, luồn vào
▪ The dog wriggled under the fence and escaped into the street.
wriggle free
len, luồn, lách khỏi
▪ Shelly tried to wriggle free from him, but he held her firmly.

children.name: writhe
children.definition: /raɪð/  to twist your body from side to side violently, especially because you are suffering pain:quằn quại
examples: ▪ As he received each blow, he writhed on the floor and cried out.
writhe in pain/agony
quằn quại trong cơn đau/đau đớn
▪ Sarah was writhing in agony, clutching her leg.

children.name: when it is difficult to move st
can’t move
children.definition: /ˌkɑːnt ˈmuːvǁˌkænt-/  especiallyspokenifyoucan’t move, you are unable to move, for example because you areinjured:không thể di chuyển (bị thương)
examples: ▪ Elsie was so frightened that she couldn’t move.can’t move something
▪ I can’t move my leg - I think it’s broken.

children.name: stuck
children.definition: /stʌk/ someoneorsomethingthat is stuck is fixed or trapped in a particular position or place and cannot move or be moved:
examples: bị tắc kẹt
▪ I can’t open the window - it’s stuck.
stuck in/at/between etc
bị tắc kẹt trong/ở/giữa...
▪ The elevator was stuck between two floors.
get stuckbecome stuck
bị kẹt
▪ They tried to drive through the snow, but the car got stuck
stuck in traffic
kẹt xe
▪ Sorry I’m late. I got stuck in traffic.

children.name: jammed
children.definition: /dʒæmd/ somethingthat is jammed cannot be moved because it is trapped between two surfaces or trapped between parts of a machine:
examples: bị kẹp chặt, bị ép chặt
▪ The drawer’s jammed - I can’t get it open.
jammed in/under/between etc
bị kẹp chặt, bị ép chặt trong/dưới/giữa...
▪ The paper has got jammed in the printer again.

children.name: stiff
children.definition: /stɪf/  if your fingers, back, neck, legs etc are stiff, it is difficult and usually painful for you to move them:cứng đơ
examples: ▪ I woke up with a stiff neck this morning.
▪ After a twelve hour plane ride, my back was stiff and sore.feel stiff
▪ I felt really stiff after playing basketball last week.

children.name: paralysed
children.definition: British /paralyzedAmerican /ˈpærəlaɪzd/  when it is difficult or impossible to moveyourbody:
examples: bị tê liệt
completely/partially paralyzed
bị tê liệt hoàn toàn/cục bộ
▪ A car crash in 1997 left him completely paralysed.
paralysed with
bị tê liệt vì
▪ Deborah stood at the side of the stage, paralyzed with fear.

children.name: stranded
children.definition: /ˈstrændɪd, ˈstrændəd/  unable to move or be moved from a place:bị mắc kẹt
examples: ▪ After the flood, hundreds of stranded vehicles lined the roads.
stranded on/in/at etc
bị mắc kẹt vào/trong/ở...
▪ Whales occasionally swim too close to shore and become stranded in the shallow water.
leave somebody stranded
khiến ai đó lâm vào hoàn cảnh khó khăn
▪ My car broke down, and I was left stranded by the side of the road.

children.name: entangled
children.definition: also caught up British /ɪnˈtæŋgəld, ˌkɔːt ˈʌp/  if two or more things are entangled or caught up, they are completely twisted together so that they cannot move or separate:bị mắc vào, vướng vào
examples: entangled in
bị mắc vào, vướng vào trong
▪ His hands were entangled in the ropes.
▪ My glasses were caught up in my hair and I couldn’t take them off.
become/get entangled/caught up (in)
bị mắc vào, vướng vào trong
▪ A child swimming in the river had become entangled in the weeds and been drowned.
▪ Our umbrellas got caught up as we tried to squeeze past each other.

children.name: won’t budge/can’t budge something
children.definition: /ˌwəʊnt ˈbʌdʒ, ˌkɑːnt ˈbʌdʒ something ǁˌkænt-/  if something won’t budge, or you can’t budge it, you cannot move it even though you try very hard:không nhúc nhích
examples: ▪ Could you give me a hand with this box? It won’t budge.
▪ The dresser was so heavy that I couldn’t even budge it.
not budge (something) an inch
không nhúc nhích lấy một phân
▪ I tried to raise the window, but it wouldn’t budge an inch.

children.name: moving
children.definition: /ˈmuːvɪŋ/  not staying still, but changing position or going from one place to another:
examples: động , đang chuyển động
moving car/truck/vehicle etc
xe hơi/xe tải/xe đang chuyển động
▪ The authorities believe the body was thrown from a moving vehicle.moving part
▪ All the moving parts of the engine must be kept well-oiled.

children.name: be in motion
children.definition: /biː ɪn ˈməʊʃən/  especially written if something, especially a vehicle or machine, is in motion, it is moving from one place or position to another:đang chuyển động
examples: ▪ Do not distract the driver while the vehicle is in motion.

children.name: mobility
children.definition: /məʊˈbɪlɪti, məʊˈbɪləti/  especially written someone’s ability to move - use this especially about people who are very old, injured etc:tính chuyển động
examples: ▪ You’ll experience some loss of mobility for a few weeks after the operation.
▪ The weakening of bone tissue has a considerable effect on an elderly person’s mobility.

children.name: mobile
children.definition: /ˈməʊbaɪlǁ-bəl, -biːl/ lưu động
examples: mobile library/shop/clinic etc
thư viện/cửa hàng/bệnh viện thực hành lưu động
a library, shop etc that is in a vehicle and which moves around from place to place:
▪ Remote areas are served by a number of weekly mobile clinics.
▪ Neuman revealed that she nearly quit showbusiness to run a mobile massage parlour.
▪ The community currently receives service from a rural mobile library.

children.name: mobile
children.definition: /ˈməʊbaɪlǁ-bəl, -biːl/  especially British someone who is mobile can move and walk around normally:chuyển động
examples: ▪ He won’t be mobile for some time. It’s a bad knee sprain.
▪ Ethel needed help on the stairs, but was otherwise mobile.

children.name: to move st or sb that is difficult to move
move
children.definition: /muːv/ di chuyển
examples: ▪ I tried to open the door, but I couldn’t move it an inch.
▪ The sculpture is heavy and very difficult to move.

children.name: shift
children.definition: /ʃɪft/  British informal to move something, especially something large or heavy, from a position in which it is stuck:di chuyển
examples: ▪ The sofa is stuck in the doorway and I can’t shift it.
▪ There’s no point trying to shift the car by ourselves -- we’ll have to get a truck to pull us out.

children.name: free
children.definition: /friː/  to move something or someone from a position in which they are stuck or being held, especially with a sudden forceful movement:gỡ ra khỏi
examples: ▪ We’re going to need some rope to help free the girl.
free somebody/something from something
gỡ ai đó/cái gì đó ra khỏi cái gì đó
▪ Kirk battled for eight hours to free himself from the wreckage.
▪ Susan managed to free her right hand from her attacker with a violent twisting movement.
struggle to free yourself
vùng vẫy để thoát khỏi
▪ The horse’s eyes were filled with terror as it struggled to free itself from the deep, sucking mud.

children.name: release
children.definition: /rɪˈliːs/  to move something such as part of a machine from a position in which it is stuck or tightly fastened:tháo ra
examples: ▪ The bolts can only be released with a wrench.
▪ Try to release the clamp gently.

children.name: what you say to tell sb not to move
don’t move
children.definition: /ˌdəʊnt ˈmuːv/ đừng cử động, đừng đi đâu
examples: ▪ Don’t move or they’ll see us.
▪ Don’t move. I’ll be back in five minutes.

children.name: keep/stay still
children.definition: /ˌkiːp, ˌsteɪ ˈstɪl/  used to tell someone not to change position or not to move any part of their body:dừng cử động, giữ yên
examples: ▪ If you can’t keep still, how can I cut your hair?
▪ Can you keep still for a minute, Kim?
▪ Be quiet and stay still.

children.name: freeze
children.definition: /friːz/  used especially by police officers to tell someone to stop moving and stand completely still:đứng yên
examples: ▪ ‘Freeze! Drop your weapons!’ shouted the policeman.

children.name: stay (right) where you are
children.definition: /steɪ (ˌraɪt) weəʳ jʊ ˈɑːʳ/  used to tell someone not to go anywhere:ở yên đó
examples: ▪ Stay where you are! Don’t come any closer.
▪ I’m going to look for a telephone. You stay right where you are until I come back
